title: Toy Train with Independent Wheelbases Fits Brio and Other Tracks

description.text:
Working on a high quality printable train. Will require some non-3D printed parts. This train is designed to be compatible with Brio and other wooden train tracks.
This is still in beta. I'm hoping to garner interest in case anybody wishes to help.
My end goal is to design a complete replica of the Polar Express.
UPDATE: 10/4/2014

  • I went to a local hobby shop and found 1/8" brass tubing. It's 3.125mm so pretty close to the 3mm I was planning for. I designed the openings to be 3.5mm so it should fit. I printed the pieces with my Da Vinci but the openings didn't work, they were too tiny. So I don't know if I designed it wrong or if the Da Vinci software ruined it. I'm going to try to increase the openings in the STL files so it'll fit better.
    UPDATE: 10/5/2014

  • Increased the hole sizes of the STL files to fit the larger brass tubing I found. Files uploaded.

• 1 x Body
  • 2 x Wheelbase
  • 8 x Wheels

    2) Get all the non-print parts

  • 1/8" metal tube
  • 2 x 1/2" ring magnets
  • 10 x Round head nails
  • 2 x smaller nails? small washers? (not sure about this, yet)

    3) Insert metal tubes into base

    I'm not quite sure on the tube length. The hole I designed is 6mm deep. So you will need 4 x 3mm metal tubes approx. 12mm? Glue them into the 4 openings in the bottom of the base

    4) Nail magnets into wheelbase

    I made small holes in the front of the wheelbase for you to nail the the magnets into. Use 1 round head nail to nail the magnet into the front of the wheelbase

    5) Attach axles to wheelbase

    So basically the order goes round nail, metal tube, plastic wheel, body, plastic wheel, round nail. I'm not sure the best way to assemble these.

    6) Attach wheelbases to body

    I don't quite know the size of nail but basically the wheelbase will go into over the metal tubes sticking out of the body. The one opening in the wheelbase should be nailed in so the wheelbases stay attached to the body.

    This is a work in progress. Let me know how this works for you.

title: Pole Adapter for Expanding Foam Sealant Can

description.text:
Let me start off by stating, that I don't really expect anyone to make
this thing. I only made it to solve a problem very specific to my home.
.
I've got to say that this is what makes 3D printers so great. I can
make a custom tool which doesn't exist anywhere else (you can't
buy one) to solve a problem; and it works!
.
I have a cape code style home with a metal roof. While the metal
roof is great and the snow slides right off it in the winter, it's a
slippery surface that is dangerous to climb up on to do house
maintenance even in nice weather.
.
Anyway, I needed to do some weather sealing around one of the
dormers and didn't have any idea how I would get up there safely
to seal the gaps. I found a can of black expanding foam sealant
that would blend in perfectly. (It's really for ponds, but should work
fine on the house...)
.
While I was out looking at it, I thought it would be great if I could run
it through a hose and fill the gaps, but I knew that was impractical
because the hose length was too long. I then thought it would be
great if they had a pole adaper with a trigger I could use.
.
That's when it hit me that I could print one. I have a pole for my
roof rake that I used to use to pull snow off the roof (which I no
longer need because I have a metal roof). I used the existing
spray can cap and the roof rake pole measurements and came
up with this design.
.
I didn't need a fancy trigger because these cans work when you
put sideways pressure against the nozzle. Simply tying a string
around the nozzle took care of the trigger for me.
.
Long story short (too late for that...) It worked like a charm.
.
I'm always thrilled when I find a practical application for my 3D
printer. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy printing a Woolly Mammoth
skull (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:480452 ) as much as the
next guy, but it's not something that helps justify the cost of the
printer and filament.
.
If you do make one, bear in mind that I haven't done any safety
testing on it (what could go wrong swinging a pressurized can of
flamable goop around on a pole above your head?), that you should
wear appropriate safety gear when using it, and that you use it at
your own risk.

description.header: for every extruder with 50mm wide bores to mount
improves the sliding of your x-axis a lot!

description.text: Buy 4 pieces of "SCS8UU" linear motion ball bearings - will cost you not more than â‚¬25 ( $30). Mount those as on the picture with 16 countersunk head screws M4 (thread of the bearings is not running through the hole - so measure your srew length) Lube the inner part of the bearings with a highly viscous oil! Designed for a Wade extruder so take care before you dismantle your printer completely! http://www.ebay.de/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=p4340.m570.l2736&_nkw=SCS8UU

comments.text: It's been done, although with different bearings. If you search things before making them, it might save some time. Try searching for "lm8uu x".
comments.author: ronthomp

comments.text: But the "lm8uu" bearing is just the inner (round!) part of the one I mentioned above - using this would lead to the exact same shitty carriage I had before.
comments.author: ronthomp

comments.text: What was shitty about it? How is this better? Thanks.
comments.author: MLworx

comments.text: The alignment of the bearings is much better using not only the inner part of the bearing (the bearing itself) - by using the housing (steel) you have the correct angles and mount it on a straight plate instead of a printed, round (?) housing.
comments.author: ronthomp

comments.text:
Thanks, I never experienced these problems. My first printer used the Supa Flat X Carriage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10646http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... with the bolt on PLA bushings. I redesigned them to use the LM8UU bearings. Since they bolt on, there are no alignment problems.

author: Mundoreal

title: Pringles Can Straw Dispenser (for big printers)

description.text:
Good straw dispensers are expensive and most break easily. So I decided to make one out of a Pringles can.
The main bar is a good 245mm long so you will need a large prints, it may fit your printer if you turn it 45 degrees.
I printed on a TAZ 4 with ABS and used Acetone to glue up all the parts.

Simply print and assemble as shown. I printed the knob and main rod with very sparse infill (10%) and the bottom and top plates solid.
If you print with ABS you can use acetone to glue together (PLA use Super glue or epoxy).
The rod fits snugly into the base and the cap and knob. Glue to base first. Then slide cap on down a ways, glue knob onto end, then add glue to the bottom edge of the knob and slid the lid up to it (knob and cap should be touching).

title: Low Poly Frog Mount (RigidBot E3D v6)

description.text:
Experimental RigidBot E3D v6 mount, requires the following parts to assemble: 2 M3x25 socket cap screws for NEMA 17 mount
9 M3x16 socket cap screws to attach the baseplate and 30mm fan
4 M3x10 socket cap screws for top clamp
3 M3x8 socket cap screws for the cooling duct and belt
1 50mmx15mm blower fan
1 Heat shield
1 E3D v6 Hotend
1 RigidBot 3D Printer Warning: This mount should have an additional heat shield on the bottom to prevent the heater block from melting the plastic above it. Warning: This design decreases the RigidBot's build height by about 2cm. Make sure to update your firmware Z height to prevent the gantry from crashing into the top of the frame. There are two different duct designs, you won't need to print both unless you plan to switch between the two. If you're looking for a RigidBot E3D v6 mount, there are a bunch of options, take a look here: http://rigidtalk.com/wiki/index.php?title=E3Dv6_Hotend_Mount edit: I added an updated (v2.11) version of this mount, but it has not been tested so I don't know if it works. The new version is wider, adds an additional E3D fan mounting location and has looser tolerances where it clamps to the E3D.
BoltDepot.com is a good source for M3 hardware if you're in the US and can't find anything locally. The largest piece in the middle may crack or warp if printed in ABS.

comments.text: I forgot to ask, is it possible that a hole was missed on the middle section that allows the side fan to pass air to the duct going up and under to the Nema motor?  I don't see how it is possible for air to get to that nicely designed vent under the Nema motor?
comments.author: Blown454

comments.text: I now have the lower and middle assembled on printer along with all 3 LM8UU bearings, I am so darn impressed how well everything fit together!  The M3 holes were absolutely perfect and allowed a very snug and perfectly mated assembly.  The belt teeth were perfect as well, I flipped the belt a half turn to allow the flat potion of belt to ride along the bearing side as that is how it is designed.  I have never done that before, but it makes sense I suppose.  I am going to add some pictures tomorrow, hopefully I will be able to say I am completed with E3D install by then as well.  I printed everything with a SLA printer except I printed one piece in ABS with the Rigidbot before taking it apart.  The part I printed in ABS for a spare was the lower bearing holder, the gear teeth (for belt clamp) on it are a bit snug and I couldn't get the belt started in it, but the LM8 bearings fit nicely when I dry fit before hand.  Oh yeah, I also printed the fan ducts in ABS on the Rigidbot, but am going to print those on the SLA printer as well for a nicer finish/fit.  This is probably one of the best fitting assembly's I have ever had the pleasure of working with, Thank you Walter!!
comments.author: Blown454

comments.text: Oh wow, it looks like the new version takes quantity 4 LM8UU bearings now.  Interesting new feature, and now I am really on the fence about continuing with my original version.
comments.author: Blown454

comments.text: Hello and thank you for such a beautiful design!  I am actually putting mine together right now as I just got the E3D yesterday.  The tolerances of the E3D mount were perfect when I printed the original version, just noticed a new version put up today with looser tolerances for E3D mount.  I printed the Clamps with an SLA printer so that may be why mine are perfect fit for E3D mount.  The only thing I noticed a slight problem was where the LM8 bearings mount into the bottom plate, the material right above the actual bearing is VERY thin, so when I was post cleaning up I actually wore through a hole right above one of the LM8UU bearings.  Probably not a huge problem, but I would love if there were a mm or so more in that area (if it is even possible!?).  Should I print the new version?  Any problems with original if I move forward?  Thank you again for this beautiful mount, I really think it looks great!
comments.author: Blown454

comments.text: Beautiful design, it's not for me, I have two self-built machines, but it's outstanding!

title: Maker Faire NY 2014 - Stencil Business Card

description.text: Card I designed to give out at World Maker Faire NY 2014. I experimented with engraving the text so there is only a single layer of plastic underneath the letters. The text is read by holding the card up to the light to show my Twitter username and the event. Card doubles as a MAKER stencil. The folks @lumi used the card to create a fabric print. In the photo you can see that the stenciled MAKER letters are dark blue while the other text is a lighter blue. Sized to match a credit card, it fits easily in a wallet. Experiment with this design in Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6jAhOLecvSL

author: Droneme

description.text: Tip: Scale to 50%. This is one heck of an angry bird

this is an upgrade for the ultimaker to speed up your prints. you might freak out of this idea but it helped me alot
I went from 100mm/s to 225mm/s (for simple objects)
and I went from 80mm/s to 150mm/s (for complex objects) I spray oil in the bowden tube of my Ultimaker...... yes I do. The Ultimaker is very fast because of the light weight on the hotend (as you know) But this comes with a down side, because at high speed the frixion in the bowden tube becomes bigger and this leads to filemant grinding. To get the frixion away you need oil in the bowden tube but NOT on the extruder gear. the oil did not seem to affect the print itself -Small objects won't work at these speeds because the Ultimaker can't cool it that much yet

I am going to make a Snap-on version of this!!! Please read all of the instructions before doing anything http://youtu.be/ov3Zt5FnCnI difficulty print ***
Print support material: Yes The things you need: 4x M3*10 screws
High Temperature resistant thin oil The oil I used whas for my airgun: PTFE-/Keramik Coat.
Temperature resistant around -40C to +750C
but you can try different brands. Make a small hole in the top of the bowden tube. But be gentle. you don't want the filament to get stuck when you push it through. A small hole is good!!! look at the picture to see what I meen. than on top of that you screw the Lubricator on. Only spray while you're printing!!!
one spay should do. and your done. Don't forget to make the temperature higher.
I'm printing PLA 150mm/s at a temperature of 240C!!! One last tip..... don't listen to the screaming noise of your extruder ad higher speeds :D

title: Folding TriCopter for 15.5mm with OpenSCAD Source - Remixed

description.text:
This TriCopter is a remix, inspired and based on the David Windestål design work at RCExplorer.se. If you haven't seen David's fantastic new v3.0 design, I recommed you visit his site and support him.
This design allows for the use of 15.5mm Towel Rack available at Home Depot which is significantly stronger than the 10mm x 10mm wood booms, while being very easy to obtain in the States, since Home Depot and Lowes are nearly everywhere. Plus you can edit the SCAD source to make the parts fit any size boom you wish. I remixed this design and moved things into OpenSCAD to allow for using the TriCopter as a project for a MultiRotor building workshop.
The source allows you to make each part or modify it to meet your needs. It supports wiring through the booms, as well as Naze32 (30.5mm x 30.5mm) flight controllers as well as APM mounts.
Optionally you can use LiPo strapped directly to the center of the frame instead of the combination battery & camera tray.
Motor Mounts remixed from shmorgan: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:108762
Body Base remixed from peddiparth: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:231205
BatteryTray remixed from bobunobo: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:402931
I am currently building the prototype, and hopefully have a maiden shortly. I used 28xx 1200kv Motors with Afro 30A SimonK ESCs for testing of different props, however 2212 900kv Motors with 20 AMP ESCs should be fine and reduce weight. Also note I used a stand alone Castle Creations 10 amp Switching BEC, since I am used a digital servo. Analog servo would be fine, and would draw a lot less current. For Yaw Tail Rotor servo:
I used a Savöx Micro digital servo Savöx SH-0257MG, most Micro style with Metal Gears should be fine.
Analog: Hitec HS-82MG or HS-85MG
Digital: Savöx SH-0257MG or Hitec HS-5085MG
Servo mount area space is 30mm x 13mm x 30mm
Yaw Motor Mount, acts like a rear leg, and the top tilt motor mount is retained by a M4x40mm, and you have the option of using either side or front ball links. Side give you more throw, while front is neater in appearance. You can mount and use a Mobius and a GoPro at the same time. Mobius on the upper deck, and the GoPro on the bottom tray. For FPV, I'll use my http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:230797 mounted on one boom and the cam mounted on front upper deck. Folded Size: 670mm x 100m
Unfolded: 770mm x 905mm
Measured propeller tip to propeller tip Maiden: 22-Nov-2014: Flight time 8m 23s
Props: APC 8 x 4.5 MR
LiPo: ReadyMade RC 3s 2200 @ 176g
AUW: 1052g

Print at .2mm layer height, 4 shells, 20% infill.
Recommend that all wire for tray be printed on the plate. This allows for better fitment.
Invert Wire Bend template needs to be rotated 180 degrees to print with out support.
Use 1.5mm x 1m Music Wire for Camera/Battery Tray vibration damping:
K & S Metals Part# 3942 1m rod $3.75
Grainger Item #3L592 108 foot roll $4.53 To use the Simple Legs with LEDS, use a translucent PLA or ABS, then when the LED is lit, the entire leg will glow, it's a cool effect.
Additional instructions to be developed
All parts can be printed without support, however you will need to rotate a few of them:
MicroServo Control Horn
TC Wire Bend Template
TC Yaw mount to print laying on its side. Naze32 Settings currently with base flight
TriCopter
Reverse Accel/Gyro Servo
Set MOTOR_STOP
PPM (for use with Immersion RC 4 Channel Lite, mounted under the Naze32) Planning on moving to cleanflight firmware shortly Taranas 9XD Settings
Adjustable Expo @ 0, 35%, 65% I could shorten many of the cables, possibly saving another ~40g

description.text:
Print and assemble this fascinating scientific instrument that you can use to detect the presence and magnitude of an electric charge. In addition to your printed parts, all you need is a glass jar, some aluminum foil and some glue. The only tools you need are a sharp knife and a straigt edge (although a file or sandpaper might come in handy).
Check out construction details with this YouTube video http://youtu.be/Wehg1M55aYQ and then visit http://PrintableScience.com for an ongoing forum and complete information.

author: PrintableScience

title: Drumstick Holder for YAMAHA DTX450K and similar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just got a new E-Drum set. First thing I asked myself was where to put my sticks since I have the set in the middle of the room.
I measured the diameters of the kits legs and my sticks and designed a rudimentary stick holder that can be rotated.
This one fits snug on 38mm legs and takes sticks that are about 14mm in diameter. I made the head part so that you should be able to fit different stick sizes. But I can't be sure.
If you like the design but need it to fit a different size, just ask and I might add the tinkercad links for remixing here.

Nothing much to tell. If you run into problems with the head part - like I did - use brim (have an Exacto handy!) and slow down the first layer to something like 35%
Let me know how it works for you :)

comments.text: Any tips to get the head to fit the base? The tab is so loose it's more balanced than secure.
comments.author: PurelyNicole

comments.text: PLA or ABS? My wife and I used PLA and her Vic Firth Sticks broke the smaller piece. But the larger piece clips on perfectly.

comments.text: I used PLA-PP and my Vic Firth 5B sticks fit fine.

author: brickgenerate

title: Meanwell SE-600 Power Supply - Laser cut enclosure - Rigidbot replacement

description.text:
Laser cut enclosure for a Meanwell SE-600 series power supply. Made to replace the stock Rigidbot power supply. Reuses the Rigidbot output power cable, and adds a on/off switch and uses a standard IEC-14 power cable.
Material is .22" Acrylic, printable on a single 18x24" sheet. Changes will need to be made to the profile cutouts for thicker/thinner material. I purchased the sheet from Lowes: http://www.lowes.com/pd_239981-1638-1AG2123A_0__
It uses 8 M3 socket cap screws - http://www.homedepot.com/p/Crown-Bolt-M3-0-5-x-8-mm-Zinc-Plated-Plain-Metric-Socket-Cap-Screw-3-Piece-per-Bag-803178/204808022?N=5yc1vZc2b0Z1z0sfzwZ1z0ygcx
The holes are sized to pass through to the casing.
And two #6-32 3/8" flat head machine screws to fasten the switch and plug. These two holes are sized to be tapped for #6-32 screws.
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Unbranded-6-32-x-3-8-in-Phillips-Flat-Head-Machine-Screws-8-Pack-28301/202706117
And using a screw mount C14 plug switch which is dimensionally compatible with http://www.schurterinc.com/var/schurter/storage/ilcatalogue/files/document/datasheet/en/pdf/typ_DC11.pdf

remixed_from.title: Active Cooling Fan Duct for Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge

title: Bracket for Active Cooling Fan Duct by thruit00

description.text: This is just a little thing I made because I was too lazy to go out and get some proper bolts. It's such a small silly thing but thruit00 asked if I would share, so here goes :) I needed to attach this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:295317 cooling duct to my FF creator pro but I didn't have any small bolts or screws that would fit so I made this little bracket thing and superglued it to the back of the fan duct. Works like a charm. And because the whole thing is so light it doesn't budge or fall off.. and an unexpected benefit is I can remove and put it back easily. And in the spirit of sharing .. I don't know anything about boards and stuff and I just got my first printer 2 weeks ago so I just connected the fan to an unused 12v (my fan is 12v) 500mA adapter.. just to throw it out there :)
print, measure, glue :P

comments.text: Thanks for sharing your idea with us!
comments.author: thruit00

comments.text: this is actually a neat idea. I have one of these ducts installed on my Replicator 2X and it's a royal PIA to remove the duct anytime I need to get at the extruder assembly. Plus, when I'm not using the extrudate cooling fan for a print, it just blocks the view of the print/nozzle.

title: Replacement retaining clip for Omron Tens unit.

description.text:
The Omron Pro Electrotherapy TENS unit comes with a clear plastic retaining clip that holds the unit onto the supplied belt clip. The piece is easily broken. This design is for a simpler/stronger clip.
I've added a more snug version that is half a millimeter shorter. (-half)

The original part was imaged in a flat bed scanner, measured with calipers and created as a sketch in FreeCad before being "padded" into this 3D design (with a final rotation in NetFabb basic).
Mine was done in ABS on a Da Vinci and works well. There is a half millimeter smaller version (-half) that is more snug.

A brief tutorial on making your own blast furnace for metal casting and rapid manufacturing.
…
The overview can be found here.
http://open3dp.me.washington.edu/2014/10/rapid-manufacturing-iteration-and-industry/ Video of the working assembly can be found here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FaLqah1V5_s

The files are parametric, the variables suited my purposes. When you make your own, be sure you have the correct dimensions when you compile your .scad into a .stl burnerIntakeMK6 is for cast bronze on a 3/4" ~.87" black pipe, before the interior gets threading cut into it. You can put threading into the SCAD but the threading tends to collect bubbles when invested in plaster.
…
MK7 intakes are set at a constant 3/8" and ID tolerance is .004" tighter.
MK8 intakes sizes are proportional to numberOfIntakes ID tolerance is .010" tighter. The SCAD of the Furnace I think is the most helpful, remember you can use:
"#" to highlight a module
or
"%" to make a module transparent
The furnace requires some metal cutting, most steel yards can do the two cuts you need for ~$20. You can drill and tap the metal pieces together or you can weld them. The kao wool and refractory will make it fire tight. You can order the kao wool and refractory from Seattle Pottery Supply or your local fireplace/furnace makers.

After buying the Printrbot Plus in November 2012, I noticed the 10T Pulleys on the X and Y axis were slipping.  So here's an enhanced version that will provide a long lasting grip and more customized fit.  I have printed this and use it on my bot.

When I bought my Printrbot Plus, it came with the flattened X and Y axis motor shafts, but the 10 tooth pulley had a full round shaft hole, with a very small set screw to hold this pulley in place. This worked great for a while, but unfortunately, the set screw inside the pulley was only 3mm and held in place with just the plastic of the pulley. Inevitably, this worked it's way loose and the Y axis motor pulley would migrate up and scrape against the bottom of the print bed. While scraping against the bottom of the print bed, this would produce faulty prints that were just unusable. This is a mod of the original Printrbot files posted by Brook Drumm: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16990 The details of this mod are as follows: 1) Adds a place for the 3mm nut that came with your Printrbot parts, please click "Thingview" in the above pic to see the underside of this pulley.
2) Shortens the overall length of the pulley for a more customized fit to your printer.
3) Both the original set screw, from your original pulley, and the short 3mm allen head screws, included with your Printrbot, will work with this mod.
4) Designed for the flattened motor shafts, not the old round shafts. This will not work with the old round motor shafts.
5) All files associated are configured for ABS plastic.
6) The Gcode file was created using Slic3r 0.9.7, and is centered on X: 75 Y: 75 for either the 6 inch or 8 inch Printrbot models. Regardless of the Printrbot model you have, just download the Gcode and go.
7) The Gcode above will print 2 pulleys. It's best to do this in case one pulley doesn't come out, maybe the other one will. CAUTION: THIS IS AN ADVANCED PRINT. While the Gcode above is optimized for all Printrbot models, this is a highly detailed print that will take 2 hours to complete. If your Printrbot is not fully calibrated, on all axes, than this will not be a usable part. Please be sure you have a few 3D prints under your belt before attempting this one. Have a look at some of my other projects for a little printing practice. The STL file above has been cleaned and optimized using Netfabb. If you haven't done so already, please print my "Printrbot Y-Axis Mod" so you can level your print bed and give your current 10T pulley some clearance under the print bed. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:48299 Thank you,
Tom Heibel

remixed_from.title: Playable Ukulele - Printable w/ no Supports

description.text: I am working on a redesign since my neck warped.  If you print this project, I recommend storing without tension on the strings (have to re-tune each time you play).  If you do this should last a long time.

This is a 3D printable guitar!
  • The whole thing is printed. You don't need anything else but some super glue to assemble the guitar.

  • Add some strings and standard guitar tuning machines and you're done!

  • It is about 3/4 scale and is very playable.
  • See a video and hear what it sounds like here: http://youtu.be/_2lzZFKssrQ

comments.text: Design it with an 6-8 mm threaded rod through the neck which should also help align the neck pieces. Leave a recessed hole at the butt there it attaches to the body for an tensioning nut. You might also consider designing the neck with a (very) slight back bend. Then if you need more curve in the neck you loosen the nut and if you need to take some of the curve out you tighten the nut. You'd have to take the neck off to make adjustments but once it's set it should be good

A library of Tortuous Tortures all derived from the original torture test by MAKE. Some of these are currently impossible to print, or at least very challenging, so they should serve as a benchmark for the development of 3D printing as a technology. They are also in response to the growing culture of 3D printing - the Pokemon effect of wanting to make and complete collections, and the perpetual race (and disappointment) of printing quality.

All meshes have been checked for errors and should be good to go. Print at your own risk. 
I may add more files to the library so I've marked as a Work in Progress.

title: Alternative gear and worm gear for Inmoov Robot shoulder

description.text: I found that the original gear and worm gear pair for hairygael's Inmoov Robot's shoulder seemed to bind a bit, so I designed a pair which seem to operate a bit more smoothly.

PLEASE NOTE!  II have modified the involute profile gear and worm gear slightly.  The worm gear was modified a bit to turn more freely and the involute profile gear now includes the slot for mounting the potentiometer which I had forgotten to include in the earlier version.
I printed these parts in ABS on an UP! Pro 3D printer at normal print speed and using a .3 mm layer with an infill level one step below 100% infill, viz, almost solid.

comments.text: Great, I'm glad to see remixes. First the cylinder of the gear is now round when mine was with faces which had to be smoothed. Does the angle on the gear helps? When I used mine I didn't have bind, but no slack either. Grease is really important because there is pressure on the parts. Plastic parts will worn with time, that is for sure.
comments.author: Gael_Langevin

comments.text: The angle of the teeth needs to match the pitch of the worm gear unless you want backlash or binding.  I was curious, though.  It seemed like the pitch angle for the worm gear was about 20 degrees while your involute profile gear had a pitch angle, I estimate, of about 32 degrees.  I reset both to 20 and wound up with a gear radius of 31.5 degrees to get a no-backlash fit. Was there some design protocol you were using there or did you develop that gear pair intuitively?

title: Umbrella Revolution Key chain (Hong Kong peaceful protest for democracy)

description.text:
Please print the logo in yellow to support us!
DO NOT print in BLUE! Please also see
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:482531

Fight for Democracy!
Support Hong Kong's Umbrella Revolution

Brief introduction of umbrella revolution (from wiki): In September 2014, pro-democracy campaigners in Hong Kong protested outside the government headquarters and occupied several major throughfares to protest against the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress' decision on proposed electoral reform which ruled out genuine democracy for the forthcoming 2017 Hong Kong Chief Executive election. The name Umbrella Revolution was possibly first used by Twitter user @Aureliano_no_24 on September 26 to describe the Hong Kong protest and has been used by many sources since a large number of protestors used umbrellas to defend themselves from pepper spray and tear gas.[2][3][4][5][6]
Student groups Hong Kong Federation of Students and Scholarism began protesting outside the government headquarters in the week of 22 September 2014.[7] In the evening of 26 September, a group of several hundred demonstrators breached a security barrier and entered the plaza in front of the Central Government Complex, which has been barred from public entry since 2014 following "security concerns". They soon were cordoned off by police and blockaded overnight, which caused more protestors to join the protest and surround the police. This led to a stand-off which lasted over a day, during which police attacked unarmed protesters with shields, batons, and pepper spray. Occupy Central with Love and Peace announced that they would begin their civil disobedience campaign with immediate effect.[8]
Around noon on 28 September, protesters spilled onto Harcourt Road and proceeded to occupy Queensway as well, blocking both east-west arterial routes on northern Hong Kong Island. After several hours of stand-off, police dispersed the crowds with tear gas and water cannons, and threatened to open fire with rubber bullets if crowds did not leave the scene.
More on NBC News:
http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/hong-kong-protests/hong-kong-protests-spread-umbrella-revolution-takes-hold-n213771

My previous garden sprayer holders worked great except one problem: the snug hold makes it certain they'll eventually break, and ABS and PLA aren't up to preventing that. This one is designed to just be a hook for the sprayer head to hang loose in, even at a silly angle. There's also a bit of strengthening on the joint to make breaks less likely.

I suggest PLA. ABS is likely to eventually warp in the sunlight. Of course, if you're using a CNC or something, so much the better! Plastic is good for this, but something stronger would be better.

description.text:
Once I started printing in Nylon I needed something to test the strength and endurance of the parts I made. 95%+ infill and 8 perimeters make for a durable wheel. The last pic is of two wheels in order to show the delamination that can occur at the edges. These where on a long-board that was towed behind a golf cart while my son tried to "drift" them. They have surprisingly good traction on concrete and asphalt. NO traction on flooring.
I included the .ipt so that you could adjust the inner diameter to fit what your printer does. I found that I could adjust the bearing hole size by adjusting the flow rate of the extruder.
Let them hydrate. Nylon gets tougher after it absorbs water.

NYLON
Parts are in mm
260C Extruder
80C Bed
gluestick
8 perimeters
solid or near solid infill.
.4 mm layers
Let them hydrate. Nylon gets tougher after it absorbs water.

comments.text: I looked back at my ordering history and I've printed 53 pounds of it so far on my rostock max. Like all Nylon it needs to be Dry. Nylon can absorb 10% of its weight in water in a 24 hour period. This flashes out as steam causing a weak and "fuzy" print. I dry mine in the oven at its lowest setting for about 8hrs. It then goes in a sealed dry box with desiccant in it. A small tube from the bottom of the box feeds my EZstruder. Air goes into the box at the same volume of filament that goes out. I have a humidistat inside the drybox. When it gets above 10% my prints start to degrade and it is hard to get the first layer to stick. I take everything out and dry it again. I print at 75c bed and 275C hotend. Washable Purple glue stick applied on a cold glass bed gets it to stick. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003VPAEL6/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

author: hyyun2

title: Auto-retracting insulated cover for Solidoodle heated bed

description.text: Bring the heated bed of your Solidoodle up to temperature twice as fast with these parts, some sheet cork, and a little plywood or mdf.  Cork has good insulating properties and is relatively heat resistant.  This mechanism is designed to auto-retract, meaning that you can leave it unattended on the lowered bed and it will flip safely out of the way when the bed raises up to print.

1) Print out the carriage, two curved support arms, three cross rods, and bed attachment collar.
2) Clean all pieces, paying particular attention to make at least two of the rods smooth and round.  I did this by gripping them with sandpaper after chucking them into a spinning drill.
3) Cut a sheet of mdf or thin plywood to 120mm x 130mm.  I used some leftover floor laminate.  
4) Drill and countersink two holes in the 1/4" plywood or mdf and attach one of its shorter sides to the bed attachment collar using screws, nuts, and the printed holes.  The screws should go in the countersunk side first and then through the collar and nut.
5) Glue cork sheet onto the plywood or MDF, covering the screw heads.  I used two layers of 1/8" cork and contact cement.
6) Slide one of the smooth rods through the holes in the bottom carriage, and the other through the attachment collar.  
7) Following the layout in the photos, connect the two arms together so that they are parallel to each other using the three rods and six small screws.  The bed attachment collar goes on the end of the long sections of the arm, while the rod going through the carriage goes on the other end.
8) Test fit the assembly to the bottom right corner of the Solidoodle case, carefully sliding the case edge into the slot in the back of the carriage.  Make sure it is properly aligned to the bed and is clear of the extruder when the latter is in the home position  The rounded support arms are designed to slide along the corner of the bed as it raises up from the rest position, so make sure the near one is not too close to the front edge of the bed.
9) Affix the carriage to the case to keep it from being lifted up by the bed. You can use hot melt glue or with screws and nuts after punching holes in the solidoodle frame that match the mounting holes in the carriage.
10) To use the cover, home the print head and lower the bed to near its bottommost position.  Flip the bed cover down onto the bed.  When the bed raises to print, it pushes the cover up and over.  About halfway up the cover's center of gravity will pass over the pivot in the carriage, causing the bed to flip completely out of the way.
11) To be useful, you probably want to add starting gcode in your slicing app that will pause a print until the bed has reached a particular temperature.  Once this is done, you can just lower the bed, put on the cover, and start a print job.  Once the bed warms up, the cover will flip out of the way when the bed raises up to begin extruding.

comments.text: Well, what is more important is the path in which the layers are laid down. Different paths can produce different rigidities in the same thickness material. The problem with bending is the same reason why Plywood is so useful. With each layer having a certain direction in which it is most elastic (normally parallel to the direction is which the plastic is laid), If you criss-cross the directions in the layers, the elasticity of the material itself is going to be negated. This is because the object will be as elastic as it's least elastic part...which turns out not to be very elastic

description.text: I need a way to quickly attach and detach my embedded electronics boards in various places. the Yazzo Harness http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4841 is where I start. I put my board into a harness, because dealing with mounting screws can be a pain. Then I attach one of these button 'snap' connectors to the back of the harness using double sided sticky tape. I could also use a Yazzo hole connector, but typically not in this case. The, I stick the 'socket' onto some surface, like the outside of the MakerBot, and I can easily plug the board into the socket and have it attached to the machine. Since it is a snap connector, like a button, yoiu can just snap it back out of there in a jiffy. I like this because you don't have to spend time repeatedly screwing and unscrewing M3 screws in those holes, with standoffs and the like. So, there you have it. A simple little connector system. There is one benefit to the early stage of this design. Since the socket only uses two prongs, instead of all four, the snap (attached to your thing) can move slightly in the track of the socket. You can easily print a thing with all 4 prongs, by altering the .scad file, or you can wait for the next modification. In the future, I will be adding a round snap button as well, which will give you rotational ability.

1) Print out a pair - Best at 0.2mm, solid, fine
2) Attach the socket to a place you want to attach something, using double stick tape, or a Yazzo hole connector. (like the side of your MakerBot
3) Attach the 'snap' to something you want to place where the socket is, like a motor driver held in a Yazzo Harness.
4) Press the snapped/harnessed electronics board in the socket
5) Rejoice! The printing is the hardest part. I use a Up! printer, which easily has the ability to print at .2mm layers, with solid. Your mileage may vary. It does not work particularly well at .3 mm, at least not on the Up! printer.
This is a remix of Will Bradley's Tactical Arduino, but optimized for the Arduino Uno's amount of things-protruding-from-the-board. Also made it around 20% cooler.

This design was made for laser cutting in CorelDraw, which only runs on Windows because Corel hates freedom and baby animals. Formatted for cutting/etching using NYC Resistor's Epilog laser cutter. Blue lines are set to cut, and any fill is set to etch. More info on NYCR's laser wiki: wiki.nycresistor.com/wiki/Laser_Power
Acrylic used can be aquired at eStreePlastics: www.estreetplastics.com/Transparent_Orange_Plexiglass_3_16_Thick_p/t051871212.htm. Recommended dimensions are 12"x12"x3/16" sheets of black and translucent orange plexiglass. I recommend against using fluorescent orange since that just sort of looks raver-y and not isolinear-chip-from-star-trek-y.

title: Ikea Markor cd cabinet hinge pivots

description.text:
These are to replace the little plastic pivots that take the full weight of the cd's and shelves.
The parts are no longer available from Ikea so these save me from scrapping the cabinet.

Designed in open scad.
This was the first thing ive ever drawn with scad
Each shelf takes 2 of each.
Printed in pla on my prusa i2 with 0.3mm nozzle.
In Cura.
layer .1
Shell .66 gives 2 layers with my .3mm nozzle.
Fill 50%
Temp 215c
bed 65c on kapton tape
